0: The mother of Casey Anthony, the Florida woman accused of killing her 2-year-old daughter, broke down in tears today during her daughter's murder trial. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Cindy Anthony choked back tears as she described a playhouse built for Caylee, Casey Anthony's daughter, who was not seen for a month before anyone reported her missing in July 2008. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "It's patio stones, it's the square patio stones, we made like a four, we didn't want her to be on the grass when she was sitting in there playing," she said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The prosecution asked Cindy Anthony to outline what kind of life Caylee Anthony was living at her grandparents' home with her mother, Casey. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR At one point during the testimony, Cindy Anthony asked the judge to take Caylee's picture down from her monitor so she could try to testify without crying. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Cindy Anthony also outlined day by day, all of the lies and excuses that her daughter, Casey Anthony, told her, as to why she couldn't talk to her granddaughter. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Casey Anthony told her there'd been a car accident or she was at work or was in Jacksonville. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Caylee Anthony was last seen alive June 16, 2008, but wasn't reported missing until July 15, 2008. Her remains were found in December of that year. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Cindy Anthony's testimony comes a day after witnesses testified they smelled human decomposition in the trunk of Casey Anthony's car. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Earlier in the morning, ex-boyfriend Tony Lazzaro testified that Casey sent a text message that said, "If they don't find her, guess who gets blamed and spends eternity in jail." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Smell of Death NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Anthony's father, George, said he discovered maggots and smelled "something that you never forget" when he opened the trunk of his daughter's car. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR George Anthony along with wife, Cindy, arrived at a tow yard on July 15, 2008 to retrieve the Pontiac Sunfire that Casey Anthony had abandoned. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He testified that he said a quick prayer that the odor was not from his missing granddaughter or his daughter. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR George Anthony said that he smelled a "pretty strong odor." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "I was very concerned about the odor," he said. "I had smelled something like that some years prior and I was concerned." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Casey Anthony's father, an ex-police officer, testified that the odor was that of a decomposing human body. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "That particular smell whenever you smell it, it's something that you never forget," George Anthony said. "It's a very distinct odor." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He did not find any dead bodies, but a bag full of trash and maggots. Forensic evidence in Anthony's car will be key in the murder trial, experts have said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The car tested positive for chloroform and human decomposition and a strand of Caylee's hair was found in the car's trunk. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Friday morning's testimony about Casey Anthony's car marked a shift from days of former friends and family testifying about Casey Anthony's behavior in the days she knew her daughter was missing but hadn't alerted authorities. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Cindy Anthony ultimately called 911 that day to report Caylee was missing and that her daughter's car smelled like there had been a dead body in it. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The supervisor of the tow truck company that removed Casey Anthony's abandoned car while her daughter, Caylee, was missing also testified Friday that the car smelled like a dead body had been in it. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Simon Birch, the operations manager for Johnsons Wrecker Service during the summer of 2008, said the car had been on the tow yard's lot for three days when he examined the car's exterior in early July. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "I put my hand up to the glass to shield the sun and look through the windows. At that point, I did notice a fairly strong odor emanating from the vehicle," Birch said. "The instant flash in my mind was, whoah, I know what that smells like." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Birch, a 30-year veteran of the towing industry, told jurors that he can tell the difference between the smell of human decomposition and the smell of garbage. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Birch said that when he and George Anthony opened the car door, "the smell came out very instantly … very potent. It was eye opening…. In the back of my mind, I said to myself that' s the smell of decomposition."
